title: Case 21 Ellie Psychological Management of Tinnitus in
chief_complaint: I worry that the ringing in my ears means I might have a serious illness like a stroke. I need my parents to check my temperature to make sure I am okay.

problem_summary.course: Infrequent; stress-triggered; most bothersome at night when trying to sleep.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral (implied by 'ear ringing' and bilateral test results)
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Headaches, dizziness, obsessive fears about illness (OCD), anxiety in enclosed spaces.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Sleep disturbance requiring white noise; significant distress and reassurance-seeking behaviors; avoidance of triggers.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: To understand the medical meaning of the ringing and reduce fear.

history.present_illness: Evaluation in September 2018. Tinnitus began in Dec 2017. Described as infrequent, triggered by stress. Most bothersome at night. Patient denies simultaneous tinnitus and headaches.
history.otologic_history: Denied history of ear infections, ear pain, or aural fullness.
history.medical_psych_history: Referred for Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) and health-related anxiety. Fears include Lyme disease, meningitis, and stroke. Triggers include dirt, hospitals, and physical symptoms.
history.prior_management: Family uses a white noise machine to facilitate sleep. Patient seeks reassurance from parents (e.g., checking temperature).

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Reliable responses to pure-tone air-conducted stimuli were obtained in the normal range for both ears.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Could not be assessed due to patient anxiety regarding the test (fear of being confined in the testing room).

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Distortion-product otoacoustic emissions (DPOAEs) were present, consistent with normal outer hair cell function.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing sensitivity bilaterally, evidenced by pure-tone thresholds within the normal range and SRTs of 5 dB HL. Middle ear function is normal (Type A tympanograms) and outer hair cell function is intact (DPOAEs present). The tinnitus is not associated with peripheral auditory pathology.
counseling_points: Your hearing test is completely normal, and your ears are healthy.
The ringing you hear is not a sign of a dangerous illness like a stroke.
Checking your body or asking your parents for reassurance might make you feel better for a moment, but it actually keeps the fear going.
We recommend working with a therapist on 'exposure' exercises to help you get used to the sound so it doesn't scare you anymore.
notes_for_actor: Portray a 10-year-old with visible anxiety, specifically health-related.
Express fear about the testing booth (claustrophobia/fear of being trapped).
Ask the clinician 'What does the ringing mean? Is it something bad?'
If parents are portrayed, they should appear eager to reassure you, which you immediately seek out.
